Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants, especially women, graduate students, postdocs, and junior faculty, in the "Waves and Spectra: Analysis/PDE Conference" that will be held from January 11-14, 2011, on the campus of Texas A&M University.

This conference will cover a variety of topics in analysis (e.g., mathematical physics, dynamical systems, spectral theory), with partial differential equations serving as a key unifying theme. All of the conference topics are central to analysis and extremely active subjects of current research. The format of the meeting is such that young people will have ample opportunities to speak and be otherwise engaged in the various conference activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award partially funded two mathematical conferences held at the department of mathematics at Texas A&M University in January 2011 and in August 2012.

The conferences pertained to several important areas of modern mathematics, such spectral and harmonic analysis and mathematical physics.

The conference on Waves and Spectra, held in January 2012, brought together experts, junior researchers and graduate students working in the areas of spectral problems for partial differential equations, mathematical physics and harmonic analysis. Four minicourses, emphasizing the interaction between these areas were given by the leading experts. In addition, ten 1-hour talks were delivered, along with a problem session and discussion panel, that especially benefited the junior participants and graduate students, who constituted the majority of participants. Other activities included a breakfast for women, who constituted more than one third of all participants.

Building on the success of the first conference, a concentration week on Recent Advances in Harmonic Analysis and Spectrtal Theory was held in August 2012. The workshop followed a similar format as the conference, with four minicourses and eight 1-hour talks delivered by the experts. In addition, the meeting included a number of shorter talks by junior participants and graduate students, who presented their research to the experts and had a chance to receive valuable feedback. Similarly to the first conference, the majority of participants were junior researchers, graduate students and/or female mathematicians.
